keyTakeAways: Royal jewels, including a tiara and earrings from Queen Marie-Amélie and Queen Hortense, and the crown of Empress Eugenie, were stolen in a daylight robbery at the Louvre museum in Paris.
The estimated value of the stolen items is $102 million (or 88 million euros), with the Louvre curator and Paris prosecutor confirming the economic and historical damage.
The theft occurred over the weekend using a crane to break a window at the Apollo Gallery, with thieves escaping on motorcycles and the incident lasting only seven minutes.
The Louvre's director, Laurence des Cars, had previously warned of security obsolescence, and the incident has intensified public and political concern about museum safety.
French authorities have noted a lack of surveillance, with only a quarter of one wing covered by video systems, and security staff reductions despite rising visitor numbers.
A 24-year-old Chinese woman was detained in Barcelona for allegedly disposing of melted gold nuggets from a previous heist at the Natural History Museum.
Additional museum thefts, including a $7.6 million heist in Limoges, have raised broader concerns about museum security across France.
The Louvre is expected to reopen after a two-day closure for investigation and is one of the world’s most visited cultural sites, with over 8.7 million visitors in 2023.
The theft has prompted calls for urgent security reforms and increased staffing, with Labour unions criticizing cuts to security personnel despite growing public attendance.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Royal jewelry from French historical queens, including items from Queen Marie-Amélie, Queen Hortense, and Empress Eugenie, was stolen in a daring daylight robbery at the Louvre museum in Paris, with a total estimated value of $102 million. The thieves, masked and armed with a crane, broke into the Apollo Gallery in just seven minutes and escaped on motorcycles, with the crown of Empress Eugenie found outside the museum. The incident has sparked national outrage, prompting criticism of long-standing security deficiencies, including only a quarter of one wing being under video surveillance and cuts to security staff despite rising visitor numbers. The Louvre’s director, Laurence des Cars, had previously warned of these risks, and the case has intensified calls for urgent security reforms. A 24-year-old Chinese woman was detained in Barcelona for a previous heist at the Natural History Museum involving stolen gold, and a similar $7.6 million theft occurred in Limoges. French authorities and the Court of Auditors have documented repeated delays in security upgrades since 2019. The museum is expected to reopen after a two-day closure, and the theft has drawn both public and political attention to the fragile state of cultural heritage security in France.
